comment.author: 18885703@N00
comment._content: Temperance bars were not uncommon, once- Lancashire had several, and I think a few are still in business... www.visitengland.com/ee/idea/Food-drink/Mr-Fitzpatricks-T... ...here in Bristol we had Simon Short, a missionary who opened a coffee house for sailors so that they didn't have to go and get drunk (which sailors are usually contractually obliged to do as soon as the gangway goes down, of course) -he used to get thrown into the harbour on a fairly regular basis.... www.flickr.com/photos/belvedere/752259839/

comment.author: 14259554@N07
comment._content: Looks like a bike for a very tall person.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I was going to say that the blue house must be No.4 but the 1895 25" OS Map shows that there were two additional houses to the south end of the terrace so you are correct with the location. This would make the Temperance Bar No.5 Tivoli Terrace.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There's no gears on the bike and a fairly high gearing ratio. I wouldn't like to cycle that up a hill.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
The crazy differences in ages noted on the face of the census continues

Thomas 48 to 67
Hanoria 46 to 69
Catherine 18 to 26

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Wonder if Josephine (Thomas' daughter) who was a "Waiteress" worked in the family business? Either way, she'd taken herself off elsewhere by 1911.

Odd! That's the first time I noticed that the "How many children / How many children still living" question doesn't appear on Form A in 1901, but only in 1911...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/belvedere] Think that the Mount Herbert Hotel here in Dublin was still a temperance hotel until quite recently. It's now the Sandymount Hotel.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] My theory (for the older ones) is that the lied about their age in 1901 out of vanity but gave their real age in 1911 to secure the pension.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: They may have had a problem with alcohol but nicotine was clearly acceptable. Two large ads for Goodbody's Cigarettes on the window. T.P. & R Goodbody's were an Irish tobacco company based in Tullamore. www.offalyhistory.com/articles/93/1/When-Tullamore-had-a-...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] have heard that before, there has to be some truth in it, as it seems to happen in most comparisons.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] an eleven year age difference can be explained if the person had a birthday on the 1st or 2nd of April (1901 census was 31st March; 1911 was 2nd April)

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] If you just want to follow nli, bookmark: www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/?details=1 If you want to follow your own comments and conversations, bookmark: www.flickr.com/activity Those pages are still pretty usable..

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] You're making an old library very very :(

I'd hate to think that any of you who've been working so hard on all kind of investigations both on and off topic, that are adding so much of value to what we know or thought we knew about (y)our photographic collections (and having so much craic at the same time, I believe) would abandon what we're doing here because the medium has changed.

And thanks for the practical suggestion, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]!!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/IRISH-AMERICAN/201... So the Strands lived at 4 Tivoli Terrace, Notice difference in Spelling! From: "Rosemary" Subject: [IRISH-AMER] Seeks Brother 1909 Date: Mon, 18 Jan 2010 16:32:24 -0500 Lowell Sun Lowell, MA 22 Feb. 1909 Mrs. Thomas Strand of 4 Tivilly Terrace, Lisdoonvarna, County Clare, Ireland, writes to the Sun for information as to the whereabouts of her brother, Michael Lally, who was a resident of this city. Lally was born in Lahinch, County Clare, and left the Cliffs of Moher about forty years ago. His wife's maiden name was Bridget Droney. When last heard from, which was about 25 years ago, Lally was in Lowell looking for the sister who is now searching for him.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] They seem to have incorporated part of No. 5 into the family home. The window immediately to the left of the archway is now part of No. 5.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I assume the bicycle has early caliper (centre-pull)-type brakes with these kind of levers?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Odd thing about the 1901 Census House and Building Return - Thomas Strand is listed as owning a Lodging House (despite being listed as a shop keeper in the census form) and a James Strand is listed as owning four properties, three of which are dwelling houses and the fourth I can't make out. Also living next door to James Strand there are two Bridget Droneys (mother & child) (c.f. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06]'s comment above)
